attributes.title: Treasures of the Earth: Power
attributes.description_short: Drill underground to see the treasures that power our world—today and into the future.
attributes.description_long: Drill down to discover the treasures beneath our feet that power our world. Fossil fuels–coal, oil, and natural gas–powered the industrial revolution and allowed us to build a way of life that many cherish today. Personal cars, planes, lights, hot showers–all of these are gifts from our fossil fuels… but they have a dirty dark side in that they are polluting the planet.

attributes.title: Treasures of the Earth: Metals
attributes.description_short: What is it about the nature of metals that have made them a pillar of human civilization?
attributes.description_long: The enduring luster of gold, the conductivity of copper, the strength of steel—the special properties of metals have reshaped societies and defined eras; they have such an important role in human history that entire ages have been named after them. But what gives metals their astounding characteristics?

attributes.title: Treasures of the Earth: Gems
attributes.description_short: What processes in the depths of the Earth forge beautiful and precious stones?
attributes.description_long: Their beauty has captivated us for millennia. Their cost can be extraordinary–some are even considered priceless. Precious gems like diamonds, rubies, emeralds, opal, and jade are the ultimate treasures of the earth, and each one is made from a specific–and often torturous–recipe of chemistry, pressure, and heat. The secrets to their sparkle, color, and even strength lie deep inside the gems.

attributes.title: Super Tunnel
attributes.description_short: Join engineers as they build a massive new railway deep beneath the streets of London.
attributes.description_long: Underneath the streets of London, a team of more than ten thousand construction workers race to build a brand new metro line—Crossrail. Costing almost $23 billion, it’s the biggest engineering project in Europe and must link into the existing metro system. As they burrow the 26 miles of tunnels, engineers battle to ensure historic buildings don’t crack and London Underground trains keep running.

attributes.title: 15 Years of Terror
attributes.description_short: From 9/11 to today’s crowd-sourced violence, trace how terrorists’ strategies have evolved
attributes.description_long: On September 11, 2001, an unimaginable horror unfolded that devastated a nation and the world. Fifteen years later, we are still gripped by terror, but it has transformed. The attacks have been coming fast and furious—to Boston, Paris, Brussels, San Bernardino, Orlando, Nice—but they are no longer commanded by a central entity. This is terrorism in the age of the Internet: crowd-sourced violence.

attributes.title: School of the Future
attributes.description_short: How can the science of learning help us rethink the future of education for all children?
attributes.description_long: In a new age of information, rapid innovation, and globalization, how can we prepare our children to compete? Once the envy of the world, American schools are now in trouble. How can the latest research help us fix education in America? Can the science of learning—including new insights from neuroscientists, psychologists, and educators—reveal how kids’ brains work?

attributes.title: Bombing Hitler's Supergun
attributes.description_short: Discover how Allied forces conspired to destroy one of Hitler’s most diabolical weapons.
attributes.description_long: Spring 1943. World War II is slowly beginning to turn in favor of the Allied forces. But, growing desperate, Hitler hatches plans for a diabolical weapon: a bank of “superguns" housed in a massive underground complex in Nazi-occupied northern France. Together the guns would be able to pump 300 heavy high explosive shells into downtown London every hour—a target 100 miles away.

attributes.title: Operation Lighthouse Rescue
attributes.description_short: Join engineers as they race to rescue a historic lighthouse from certain doom.
attributes.description_long: On the picturesque bluffs at the very tip of the island of Martha’s Vineyard, disaster looms. The historic Gay Head Lighthouse is soon to become the next victim of the persistent erosion of the island’s cliffs. Built in 1856, the more than 400-ton structure soars 175 feet above the sea. But over the years, storms and the raging ocean have eroded the headland away.

attributes.title: Great Human Odyssey
attributes.description_short: Follow our ancient ancestors’ footsteps out of Africa and into every corner of our planet.
attributes.description_long: Our ancient human ancestors once lived only in Africa in tiny bands of a few thousand hunter-gatherers. Then we moved out of our African cradle, spreading rapidly to every corner of the planet. How did we acquire the skills, technology and talent to thrive in every environment on earth? How did our prehistoric forebears cross the Sahara, survive frigid ice ages, and sail to remote Pacific islands?

attributes.title: Wild Ways
attributes.description_short: Explore how newly established wildlife corridors offer hope to endangered species.
attributes.description_long: Four-lane highways may be a necessity to our modern society, but they can be a death traps for millions of animals that try to cross them. Around the world, wildlife need to roam for breeding, foraging, and to carry out their traditional migrations–but they are often blocked by ranches, farms, roads, and other human-made obstacles.

attributes.title: Vikings Unearthed
attributes.description_short: Uncover the truth behind the legendary Vikings and their epic journey to the Americas.
attributes.description_long: Uncover the truth behind the legendary Vikings and their epic journey to the Americas.

attributes.title: Creatures of Light
attributes.description_short: Deep in the ocean, animals that flash, sparkle, and glow use light to survive in the dark.
attributes.description_long: Deep in the ocean, animals that flash, sparkle, and glow use light to survive in the dark.

attributes.title: Can Alzheimer's Be Stopped?
attributes.description_short: Join investigators as they untangle the cause of Alzheimer’s and race to develop a cure.
attributes.description_long: Alzheimer’s disease strikes at the core of what makes us human: our capacity to think, to love, and to remember. The disease ravages the minds of over 40 million victims worldwide, and it is one of the greatest medical mysteries of our time. Join investigators as they gather clues and attempt to reconstruct the molecular chain of events that ultimately leads to dementia.

attributes.title: Memory Hackers
attributes.description_short: Scientists are learning how we can edit memories—and delete our worst fears.
attributes.description_long: Memory is the glue that binds our mental lives. Without it, we’d be prisoners of the present, unable to use the lessons of the past to change our future. From our first kiss to where we put our keys, memory represents who we are and how we learn and navigate the world. But how does it work? Neuroscientists using cutting-edge techniques are exploring the precise molecular mechanisms of memory.

attributes.title: Rise of the Robots
attributes.description_short: How will human-like robots change our future and how we see ourselves?
attributes.description_long: Machines are everywhere. They run our factory assembly lines and make our coffee. But humanoid robots—machines with human-like capabilities—have long been the stuff of science fiction. Until now. Fueled by an ambitious DARPA challenge, the race is on to design a robot that can replace humans in disaster relief situations. Follow the robots and the engineers that program them.

attributes.title: Iceman Reborn
attributes.description_short: Watch as Otzi, a 5000-year-old mummy, is brought to life and preserved with 3D modeling.
attributes.description_long: Watch as Otzi, a 5000-year-old mummy, is brought to life and preserved with 3D modeling.

attributes.title: Himalayan Megaquake
attributes.description_short: The 2015 quake that rocked Nepal was the biggest in 90 years—can we forecast the next one?
attributes.description_long: On April 25, 2015, a devastating earthquake rocked Nepal. As it ripped across the Himalayas, it wiped out villages and left thousands dead. Hear the harrowing stories of the Nepalese people who lived near the epicenter and of survivors trapped on Everest. Through dramatic eyewitness footage, expert interviews, and stunning graphics, NOVA reveals the anatomy of this megaquake.

attributes.title: Mystery Beneath the Ice
attributes.description_short: What’s behind the death of a tiny creature with an outsized role in the Antarctic?
attributes.description_long: Tiny, transparent, and threatened, krill are crucial to the Antarctic ecosystem. But the population of krill is crashing for reasons that continue to baffle the experts. A leading theory says that krill’s life cycle is driven by an internal body clock that responds to the waxing and waning of the Antarctic ice pack, but climate change alters the timing of the ice pack, disrupting their life cycle.

attributes.title: Life's Rocky Start
attributes.description_short: What is the secret link between rocks and minerals, and every living thing on Earth?
attributes.description_long: Four and a half billion years ago, the young Earth was a hellish place—a seething chaos of meteorite impacts, volcanoes belching noxious gases, and lightning flashing through a thin, torrid atmosphere. Then, in a process that has puzzled scientists for decades, life emerged. But how? NOVA joins mineralogist Robert Hazen as he journeys around the globe.

attributes.title: Secret Tunnel Warfare
attributes.description_short: In WW1 Allied troops tunneled under enemy lines to create the biggest explosion ever seen.
attributes.description_long: During World War I, the Allies and Germans repeatedly struggled to break the hideous stalemate of trench warfare. In the winter of 1916, Allied engineers devised a massive surprise attack: over 1 million pounds of explosives hidden in secret tunnels driven under German lines. Building the tunnels was desperate work, with tunnelers at constant risk from flooding, cave-ins, and enemy digging teams.
